title: In ‘Ad Astra,’ Brad Pitt and the Meaning of Life
text:
A scene from ‘Ad Astra,’ in which Brad Pitt plays an astronaut on a journey to find his father.

“ Ad Astra, ” featuring Brad Pitt as a pensive astronaut, is the latest in the genre of outer-space movies that are just as much about philosophical journeys as high-tech rocket rides.

The film joins the long line of movies, from “Forbidden Planet” to “2001: A Space Odyssey” to “Interstellar,” that use voyages into infinity to explore the biggest puzzles about human origins and our intimate existential drives. When characters venture into space, “there are no banalities, no distraction from confronting your internal conflicts. The focus becomes elemental. What does it mean to be a person? What is our identity? There is no escaping that question in space, especially the farther you go,” says James Gray, who directed and co-wrote “Ad Astra,” opening on Sept. 20.

Even in an infinite universe, it’s becoming a challenge to bring original ideas to space movies. The galaxy is becoming crowded with them. Natalie Portman ’s “ Lucy in the Sky” arrives in October; Ryan Gosling traveled inside Neil Armstrong ’s head in “First Man” last year. “Ad Astra” seeks a unique space by connecting mankind’s ceaseless exploration with physicist Enrico Fermi ’s famous paradox: If the universe contains hundred of billions of galaxies, why haven’t we connected with aliens yet? (Sorry, no spoilers.)

In the film, Mr. Pitt is Roy McBride, an astronaut in the near future known for his ability to remain emotionless when facing stress. He’s distant from people even when he’s home. NASA taps him to travel to Neptune to either rescue or kill his father ( Tommy Lee Jones ), a pioneering astronaut who abandoned Earth when Mr. Pitt was a teenager, and who now may be sending deadly anti-matter blasts toward the planet.

When characters venture into space, ‘the focus becomes elemental,’ says director James Gray, here with Brad Pitt on set of 'Ad Astra.' Photo: Francois Duhamel

Mr. Pitt’s father, the first man to reach one deep-space planet after another, has forever been seeking something else, only paying attention to what was not there. Does an insatiable hunger for the next thing hurt our appreciation of what we already have? Mr. Gray, presenting Mr. Pitt and Mr. Jones as restless voyagers, offers this as a mostly male character flaw.

“I think being ‘masculine’ has done huge damage to the world,” Mr. Gray confesses. “I have a daughter and two sons. I see the way my daughter is encouraged by the culture to explore her inner life and her emotions. The culture does not support that my sons should look inward. I don’t know why it would matter less to them.”

Movies have gone to space since their first flickering light. Georges Méliès made the whimsical silent short “A Trip to the Moon” in 1902. In the 1950s, space programs and the Cold War with Russia provided new inspiration. In “Forbidden Planet,” released in 1956, a year before Sputnik, 23rd-century astronauts led by a youthful Leslie Nielsen visit a planet where a technologically advanced civilization suddenly perished.

In the 1956 film ‘Forbidden Planet,’ astronauts travel to Altair IV to discover the fate of an expedition sent there decades earlier. Photo: Everett Collection

Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C. Clarke ’s “2001” in 1969 took the epic mythology of Homer’s Odyssey into the space age. There’s a mysterious alien monolith and some swanky set design, but what it’s about is mankind’s journey from ape to human to something beyond, depicted by the giant baby “Star Child” at the end, says Michael Benson, author of the 2018 book “Space Odyssey: Stanley Kubrick, Arthur C. Clarke, and the Making of a Masterpiece.”

The 1968 movie ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ with Keir Dullea as scientist David Bowman, explored themes of existentialism and evolution. Photo: Everett Collection

“These attempts to show dramas unfolding in space are the way that we try to come to terms with the inexhaustible richness of nature and reality,” says Mr. Benson, who also authored, “Cosmigraphics,” assembling illustrations people have created throughout history to map the universe. “And they’re a kind of rehearsal for what might happen.”

“Solaris,” directed by Andrei Tarkovsky in 1972 and reimagined in 2002 by Steven Soderbergh, explores the universe as an extension of our troubled minds, asking if love could be a cosmic force. So does Christopher Nolan ’s “Interstellar,” from 2014, which uses wormhole time-warps to explore how quickly our children grow up when we’re busy with our important work. In “Gravity” (2013), the void of space gives Sandra Bullock ’s character, a grieving mother, a rebirth.

Space is a blank slate that “destroys the need for specificity of social status, of class, of all these things that traditionally get hung on a story,” Mr. Gray says. “You can’t say, ‘Oh, I know what that guy’s about. I see how he’s dressed. I see the house he’s living in.’ There’s none of that. Everyone has to wear that space suit because they have to survive.”

Sandra Bullock and George Clooney played astronauts stranded in space in 2013’s ‘Gravity.’ Photo: Everett Collection

“Ad Astra” (“to the stars” in Latin) is still a movie, not a meditation. There’s a lunar battle scene reminiscent of “Mad Max.” Mr. Gray says he worked to make the science at least plausible.

“There are times when you have to stretch it a little,” he says. “If we were to be totally accurate, Brad would look almost deformed because of zero gravity. He would look very puffy. You can’t really do that. We tried to explain that he has something that shocks his musculature to stay toned.”

Space may present endless mysteries, but Brad Pitt looking good isn’t one of them.

description: The movie joins a long line of films that journey into space to examine humanity’s puzzling questions.
